top_content.subtitle: Bridging Geospatial Technology and Humanity
top_content.paragraph_1: FOSS4G is the world’s largest conference dedicated to open-source geospatial software, organized by the OSGeo Foundation. In 2026, this global FOSS4G event will be held in Hiroshima, Japan.
top_content.paragraph_2: Geospatial technology empowers communities to address real-world challenges such as disaster response, urban planning, and environmental resilience.
top_content.paragraph_3: At FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima, we will further highlight the humanitarian applications of open-source geospatial technologies — from supporting refugees to preserving cultural memory.
top_content.paragraph_4: As a "City of Peace and Reconstruction", Hiroshima is an ideal place to explore how technology can foster empathy, inclusion, and international collaboration.
top_content.paragraph_5: And of course, we invite you to enjoy Hiroshima’s unique culture and delicious cuisine to the fullest!

foss4g.title: About FOSS4G
foss4g.intro: FOSS4G is an acronym for Free and Open Source Software for Geospatial, and it represents the world's largest international conference organized by OSGeo, a non-profit organization dedicated to promoting open-source GIS. This conference, held in various locations around the world, attracts around 1,000 participants annually and has evolved into the flagship event representing the geospatial community.

hiroshima_section.title: FOSS4G 2026 Comes to Hiroshima
hiroshima_section.content: In 2026, FOSS4G will be held in Hiroshima, Japan. In this city that symbolizes peace, advocates of "free and open" geospatial information from around the world will gather. Let us expand the possibilities of open-source GIS together here in Hiroshima.

knowledge_section.title: Convergence of All Geospatial Knowledge
knowledge_section.intro: FOSS4G covers a wide range of topics including:
topics: Geospatial tool use cases and applications
knowledge_section.conclusion: It serves as a platform where participants with diverse expertise and backgrounds learn from each other and share the latest insights.

participation_section.title: Open to Everyone
participation_section.intro: FOSS4G is an event for everyone interested in maps. We welcome not only developers who write code, but also GIS users, decision-makers, researchers, students, and even beginners who are "just a little curious".
participation_section.community: Around 1,000 people participate in FOSS4G each year, and this community continues to grow. Whether you are a geospatial information professional or attending for the first time, as long as you have an "open mind", FOSS4G is your place.

closing_section.title: See You at FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima!
closing_section.content: Let us create the future of free and open geospatial together. We look forward to welcoming you in Hiroshima.

organizing_committee.description_1: The FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima organizing committee consists of dedicated volunteers from the Japanese and international geospatial community. Our team brings together expertise in open source geospatial technologies, event management, and local knowledge of Hiroshima.
organizing_committee.description_2: Detailed information about all organizing committee members will be updated as the conference approaches.

vision.title: Our Vision
vision.paragraph_1: At FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima, we explore how open-source geospatial technologies can serve humanity's greatest challenges. As a "City of Peace and Reconstruction", Hiroshima provides the perfect backdrop to examine technology's role in fostering empathy, inclusion, and international collaboration.
vision.paragraph_2: Geospatial technology empowers communities to address real-world challenges such as disaster response, urban planning, and environmental resilience. At FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima, we will further highlight the humanitarian applications of open-source geospatial technologies — from supporting refugees to preserving cultural memory.

hiroshima.title: Why Hiroshima?
hiroshima.paragraph_1: Hiroshima's commitment to peace and international understanding aligns perfectly with the open-source philosophy of collaboration and shared knowledge.
hiroshima.paragraph_2: In this special place, let us discuss together how geospatial technology can contribute to a more peaceful, sustainable, and intricately connected world, and what the future holds.

logo.title: Conference Logo
logo.description: The FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima logo embodies our wish for the coexistence of technology and humanity.
logo.paragraph_1: The intricate and delicate lines depicted in the logo are inspired by the fold marks of the "origami crane", beloved in Japan as a symbol of peace. These lines form shapes that symbolize the "connections" and "expansions" inherent in geospatial technology, while reflecting the message of peace that Hiroshima continues to send to the world. The color scheme adopts red, which symbolizes Japan and Hiroshima.
logo.paragraph_2: The origami crane is also known from the story that "folding a thousand cranes will grant your wish", and is cherished by many as a symbol of prayer, hope, and solidarity.
logo.conclusion: The gathering of people from around the world at FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima will, like a thousand paper cranes that bundle together many people's wishes, create the power to connect technology and humanity and shape a new future together.

adopt_a_ticket.title: Adopt-a-ticket
adopt_a_ticket.intro: Adopt-a-ticket is your chance to support FOSS4G 2026 by purchasing any number of extra tickets for the conference that will be donated to our wonderful workshop instructors and Travel Grant Program (TGP) receivers.

why.title: Why?
why.tgp_support: We are dedicated to running the Travel Grant Program (TGP) - a way to facilitate accessibility and diversity in the event. In addition to a monetary grant for grantees' travel and accommodation expenses handled in cooperation with OSGeo, the LOC will grant free access to the conference main days plus one workshop of choice for all Travel Grant receivers.
why.workshop_instructors: The LOC understands that preparing and conducting an educative and successful workshop takes quite some effort and time. This is the reason we are giving away free tickets to all workshop instructors.
why.belief: We do this because we believe this is the right thing to do.
why.funding_challenge: But this also means that the conference will miss out on some of the income funds although we still need to cover the related expenses (lunches, coffee breaks, etc). This is where we would appreciate your help. Instead of increasing the ticket cost for all we chose to allow you to make a conscious choice.

how.title: How does this work?
how.description: When registering for the conference, you can choose between any of the add-ons: a t-shirt, a mug, workshop tickets and so on. One of the add-ons there is called 'Adopt-a-ticket', your chance to help us raise extra funds to do the right thing.
how.opportunity: We see it equally as an opportunity for smaller organizations and individuals who would like to support the conference but for whom the existing sponsorship levels are too expensive.

benefits.title: What's in it for you?
benefits.description: With 'Adopt-a-ticket' you can purchase any number of extra tickets. In return we would like to show our gratitude by having you included in the 'Honorable mentions' section of the conference homepage. If you buy more than one extra ticket with 'adopt-a-ticket' then you would instead be eligible for any of the predefined sponsor packages in an equal amount.

supporting_participation.title: Increasing Accessibility and Diversity
supporting_participation.description: The FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima organizing committee is pleased to provide a Travel Grant Program to increase the chances of attendance and accessibility of this conference to community members, especially focusing on facilitating participation for minority groups and categories usually underrepresented.

who_should_apply.title: Who should apply
who_should_apply.description: The aim of the program is to increase the chances of attendance and accessibility of this conference to community members and it especially focuses on facilitating the participation for minority groups and categories usually underrepresented. This includes, but is not limited to:
criteria: People who wouldn't be able to attend without funding assistance.
People attending FOSS4G for the first time.
People from underrepresented communities, such as Indigenous communities; Residents of remote communities; and Women and minority genders.
Community development workers or students who don't have workplace or government funding
People who will make use of what they learn to make a positive impact on themselves and their communities.
People who contribute to open communities, such as contributing to OpenStreetMap, or open source software.

application_process.title: How to apply
application_process.description: Before submitting your TGP application, think about the key information that will help us understand you better:
key_questions: How have you and do you contribute to the community?
Do you belong to any community organisations and for how long?
Why do you need our support?
What financial assistance do you require (please be realistic)?
application_process.note: Applicant data will be kept confidential and only used for assessing TGP applications. Please ensure that the email address provided is regularly monitored as the selection committee may seek clarification of your response.

about_tgp.title: About the TGP
about_tgp.description: The FOSS4G Travel Grant Program initiative was established to facilitate accessibility and diversity at FOSS4G conferences. It is funded by OSGeo Foundation, proceeds from our generous sponsors, and contributions from organisations and individuals.
about_tgp.funding_note: Please note that the number of grants available is dependent on this funding and the number of applications we receive.
about_tgp.management: The TGP is managed by the FOSS4G 2026 Hiroshima LOC Committee.
